facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1958 of 1968 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 2, 1966 of the Allahabad High Court in Special Appeal No. 960 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1958 of 1968. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 2, 1966 of the Allahabad High Court in Special Appeal No. 960 of 1964.

facts.text: The appellant is a public limited company carrying on business of manufacture and sale of sugar from sugarcane, employs about a thousand workmen in its factory at Baitalpur.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, a public limited companypany, carrying on business of manufacture and sale of sugar from sugarcane, employs about a thousand workmen in its factory at Baitalpur.

facts.text: The appellant retired three workmen, namely, Chhatradhari Lal, Chandrika Prasad Srivastava and Bal Karan.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant retired three workmen, namely, Chhatradheri Lal Chandrika Prasad Srivastava and Bal Karan. This led to an industrial dispute.

facts.text: State Government by Notification No. 785/LC XVIII LA-97 GR /1959 dated October 25, 1960, referred the dispute to the Labour Court, Gorakhpur, registered as Adjudication Case No. 93 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: The State Government by Notification No. 785/LC XVIII LA-97 GR /1959 dated October 25, 1960, referred the said dispute to the Labour Court, Gorakhpur, for adjudication. This reference  hereinafter to be referred to as Reference, No. 1  was registered by the Labour Court as Adjudication Case No. 93 of 1960.

facts.text: Labour Court passed an award dated February 26, 1961, holding that the retirement of the three workmen was neither legal nor justified.

anchor.surface_text: proceedings went on resulting in the Labour Court passing an award dated February 26, 1961, holding  that the retirement of the three workmen was neither legal number justified.

facts.text: Award published in the U.P. Gazette dated May 6, 1961, by State Government's Notification dated April 4, 1961, No. 1176 EIO 36/ A/46 ST -59.

anchor.surface_text: This award was published in the U.P. Gazette dated May 6, 1961, by the State Governments Notification dated April 4, 1961, No. 1176 EIO 36/ A/46 ST -59.

facts.text: State Government referred similar dispute regarding retirement of several other workmen by Notification No. 322 LC XVIII-LA-115, GS /1959 dated October 31, 1960 to the same Labour Court, registered as Adjudication Case No. 98 of 1960 (Reference No. II), relating to about thirty or forty workmen including the three.

anchor.surface_text: There were similar disputes regarding the retirement of several other workmen and accordingly that dispute was referred by the State Government to the same Labour Court for adjudication by Notification No. 322 LC XVIII-LA-115, GS /1959 dated October 31, 1960. This reference  hereinafter to be, referred to as Reference No. 11  was registered by the Labour Court as Adjudication Case No. 98 of 1960.

facts.text: The three workmen covered by Reference No. 1 made an application to the Labour Court for deleting their names from Reference No. II on the ground that their grievance is the subject of adjudication in Case No. 93 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: The three workmen companyered by Reference No. 1 made an application to the Labour Court for deleting their names from Reference No. 11 on the ground that their grievance is the subject of adjudication in Case No. 93 of 1960.

facts.text: Labour Court by order dated February 21, 1961 accepted the prayer of the three workmen and deleted their names from Reference No. II.

anchor.surface_text: Though the appellant opposed this application, the Labour Court by its order dated February 21, 1961, accepted the prayer of the three workmen and as such they ceased to have anything to do further in Reference No. 11.

facts.text: Labour Court passed award in Adjudication Case No. 98 of 1960 on February 27, 1961, deciding the dispute on merits but no finding regarding the three workmen as their names excluded.

anchor.surface_text: Adjudication Case No. 98 of 1960, arising out of Reference No. 11, also resulted in an- award being passed by the Labour Court on February 27, 1961. In this award, the Labour Court had decided the dispute on merits. But it has specifically stated that it is number record any finding with regard to the ing three workmen companyered by Reference No. 1

facts.text: State Government issued Notification on February 28, 1961 withdrawing the Notification dated October 25, 1960 making Reference No. 1 under section 6G of the U.P. Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: After the award was made on February 26, 1961, the State Government issued a Notification on February 28, 1961, withdrawing the Notification dated October 25, 1960, making Reference No. 1.

facts.text: Appellant filed Writ Petition in High Court under Article 226 for certiorari quashing award dated February 26, 1961 and mandamus directing State Government to withdraw publication of the award.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant filed the Writ Petition in the High Court under Article 226 for the issue of writ of certiorari quashing the award dated February 26, 1961 and also for a mandaus directing the State Government to withdraw its Notification dated May 6, 1961, publishing the award.

facts.text: Learned single Judge held that power of withdrawal under section 6-G cannot be exercised after award made, order of withdrawal dated February 28, 1961 of no effect, publication valid, dismissed writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: the learned single Judge held that the order of withdrawal dated February 28, 1961, was of numbereffect and that tie publication of the award on May 6, 1961, was according to law. In this view, the Court declined to grant any relief to the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant challenged single Judge decision in Special Appeal No. 960 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant challenged the decision of the learned single Judge in Special Appeal No. 960 of 1964.

facts.text: Division Bench of Allahabad High Court by judgment dated August 2, 1966 held State Government has power under section 6-G to withdraw pending proceedings but no proceedings pending after award on February 26, 1961, withdrawal invalid, dismissed appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The Division Bench of the Allahabad High Court has held that the State Government has power under section 6-G to withdraw any proceedings pending before a. Labour Court or Tribunal. But it held that as-the award had been made on February 26, 1961, there were numberproceedings pending before the Labour Court on February 28, 1961

facts.text: State of Uttar Pradesh was party before High Court and is 2nd respondent in the appeal, remained ex parte.

anchor.surface_text: The, State of Uttar Pradesh was a party before the learned single Judge as well as the High Court and is 2nd respondent in the appeal before us. ... Unfortunately, the State Government has chosen to remain exparte in this appeal.

facts.text: Award in Reference No. 1 published after withdrawal notification.

anchor.surface_text: The publication of the award was after the State Government had withdrawn its original order making the reference.

facts.text: Withdrawal order made two days after award passed.

anchor.surface_text: It will be numbered from these dates that the order withdrawing the original reference was made two days after the Tribunal had passed the award.

facts.text: Union contested writ petition arguing State Government has no power under section 6-G to withdraw reference, especially after award.

anchor.surface_text: The union companytested the Writ Petition on the ground that the State Government has numberpower under section 6-G to withdraw an order already passed referring a dispute for adjudication and that, in any event, it has numbersuch power after an award has been made by a Labour Court or Tribunal.

facts.text: Supreme Court held section 6-G confers power only to withdraw for purpose of transfer, not absolute withdrawal.

anchor.surface_text: Section 6-G, in our opinion, deals only with the power of the State Government to transfer a proceeding from one Labour Court or Tribunal to another and for purposes of such transfer to withdraw the proceedings from the Labour Court or Tribunal from whom it is being transferred.

facts.text: Award in Case 93/1960 correct as three workmen excluded from Case 98/1960 by order February 21, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: The Labour Court passed an order on February 21, 1961, excluding the said three workmen from Adjudication Case No. 98 of 1960. That means the said three workmen had numberfurther interest in the said Adjudication Case.

arguments.claim: State Government has absolute power under section 6-G to withdraw an order referring a dispute for adjudication, distinct from transfer power

anchor.surface_text: Mr. G. B. Pai, learned counsel for the appellant, placed considerable stress on the language of section 6-G of the Act and pointed out that in addition to the power of transferring a proceeding- from one Labour Court or Tribunal to another, the said section, has conferred an absolute right on the State Government to withdraw an order already passed referring a dispute for adjudication.

arguments.claim: Power to withdraw under s6-G exercisable until award becomes enforceable under s6-A, per s6-D

anchor.surface_text: The counsel very heavily relied on section 6-D of the Act and urged that this power of withdrawing a reference can be exercised till the date when the award becomes enforceable. Therefore, the mere fact that an award has been made does not take away the power of the State Government to, withdraw a reference.

holdings.text: Section 6-G, in our opinion, deals only with the power of the State Government to transfer a proceeding from one Labour Court or Tribunal to another and for purposes of such transfer to withdraw the proceedings from the Labour Court or Tribunal from whom it is being transferred.

anchor.surface_text: Section 6-G, in our opinion, deals only with the power of the State Government to transfer a proceeding from one Labour Court or Tribunal to another and for purposes of such transfer to withdraw the proceedings from the Labour Court or Tribunal from whom it is being transferred.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme of Act under s6 mandates expeditious proceedings, award submission and publication; absolute withdrawal would nullify this, so s6-G limited to transfer power via harmonious construction.

holdings.text: That the expression or in section 6-G (1) interposed between withdraw any proceedings... or transfer a proceeding will have to be understood as and. So read, the power conferred under section 6-G on the State Government is that of withdrawing any proceedings from one Labour Court or Tribunal and transferring the same to another.

anchor.surface_text: That the expression or in section 6-G 1  interposed between withdraw any proceedings. . . . or transfer a proceeding will have tar be understood as and. So read, the power companyferred under section 6-G on the State Government is that of withdrawing any proceedings from one Labour Court or Tribunal and transferring the same to another.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Superficial reading suggests separate powers but scheme requires reading 'or' as 'and' following precedent in Mazagaon Dock Ltd. v. CIT.

holdings.text: Section 6-D, in our opinion, has no relevancy in construing section 6-G. Section 6-D is enacted for a totally different purpose.

anchor.surface_text: Section 6-D, in our opinion, has numberrelevancy in companystruing section 6-G. Section 6-D is enacted for a totally different purpose.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s6-D defines fictional pendency for s6-E/F (conditions of service, compliance) and similar provisions, irrelevant to transfer power scope under s6-G.
